name: Manual canopy height
description: Canopy height estimates for each single row of 2-row plots.  Measured in cm using meter stick, taken at the height representing the plot 'potential', ignoring stunted plants. The canopy height was measured as the height of the foliage (not the inflorescence) at the general top of the canopy where the upper leaves bend and/or establish a canopy surface that would support a very light horizontal object (imagining a light sheet of rigid plastic foam), discounting rare or exceptional leaves in the upper-most 2 or 3 percentile.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

radius = 16 mm

name: Harvest yield estimates Maricopa sorghum season1 mechanical harvest
description: Maricopa sorghum season1 harvest, if range =<32, then each individual row cut with mechanical harvester (Carter mfg equipment) and weighed with onboard weighing system.  Fresh weight and dry weight of the harvested plot (2 rows) expressed in kg/ha assuming plot dimensions of 1.524 m width and 3.5 m length.  Dry weight of the harvested plot adjusted to 0% moisture.  Plant moisture content (%) at harvest estimated from a subsample place in an uncooled greenhouse that reached a diurnal high temperature of 60 C before being transferred to an oven at 60 C for final drying.  Moisture content calculated as (subsamplefresh-subsampledry)*100/subsamplefresh.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Leaf porometer measurements for stomatal conductance
description: Sorghum season1 leaf porometer measurements were taken using the Decagon SC-1 Leaf Porometer, using an older unit which has no record of calibration.  The unit was used without the desiccant chamber.  In general, 5 measurements were made for each plot on sunlit leaves, the most fully developed leaves in the upper canopy that were sunlit. See manual description for specifications:  http://manuals.decagon.com/Manuals/10711_Leaf%20Porometer_Web.pdf
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Harvest yield estimates Maricopa sorghum season1 hand harvest
description: During Maricopa sorghum season1 harvest, if range > 32 select plots were harvested by hand methods.  Two 1.524 m sections of each row of 2-row plots were cut by hand with a machete, combined and placed on a tarp, and weighed using a scale hanging on a tripod. The exception is the row# study where each row was cut and weighed separately.  The cutting height was about 10 cm above ground-level. Fresh weight and dry weight of the harvested plot (2 rows) are expressed in kg/ha assuming plot dimensions of 1.524 m width and 3.5 m length. Dry weight of the harvested plot is adjusted to 0% moisture. Plant moisture content (%) at harvest estimated from a subsample place in an uncooled greenhouse that reached a diurnal high temperature of 60 C before being transferred to an oven at 60 C for final drying. Moisture content calculated as (subsamplefresh-subsampledry)*100/subsamplefresh.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Maricopa Phenotractor
description:
An array of three types of senors mounted on the front boom of a tractor were used to collect multi-spectral, thermal, and height data from the field.  Each set of sensors collected data from a single row of plants.  Canopy reflectance was measured using a GreenSeeker (RT200 System by Trimble) sensor, canopy surface temperature using an Apogee S1-121 infrared radiometer (IRT), and canopy height using a sonar proximity sensor.  The front-boom sensor array included three replicate sets of sensors in 2016 to allow three rows of plants to be measured during each single tractor pass.  Data analyses for four dates (25 Aug, 1 Sept, 8 Sept, and 23 Sept) were completed by Matthew Maimaitiyiming and Wasit Wulamu, as described in their document included here. 

"Phenotractor data
Matthew Maimaitiyiming and Wasit Wulamu
Center for Sustainability, Saint Louis University
January 6, 2017

The phenotractor was equipped with three types of sensors for measuring plant height, temperature and canopy spectral reflectance.  A RTK GPS was installed on top of the tractor, see the figure 1.
 
Figure 1. Phenotractor system configuration
The distance from canopy to sensor position was measured with a sonar proximity sensor (Soutput, in mm).  Canopy height (CH) was determined by combining sonar and GPS elevation data (expressed as meter above sea level).  An elevation survey was conducted to determine a baseline reference elevation (Eref) for the gantry field.  CH was computed according to the following equation: 
CH = Es – Eref - Soutput
where  Es is sensor elevation, which was calculated by subtracting the vertical offset between the GPS antenna and sonar sensor from GPS antenna elevation.
Infrared radiometer (IRT) sensors were used measure canopy temperature and temperature values were recoded as degree Celsius (°C).   
Canopy spectral reflectance was measured with GreenSeeker sensors and the reflectance data were used to calculate NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index).  GreenSeeker sensors record reflected light energy in near infrared (780 ± 15 nm) and red (660 ± 10 nm ) portion electromagnetic spectrum from top of the canopy by using a self-illuminated light source. NDVI was calculated using following equation: 
NDVI=(ρ_NIR-ρ_red)/(ρ_NIR+ ρ_red )
Where ρ_NIR and ρ_red represent fraction of reflected energy in near infrared and red spectral regions, respectively.  
Georeferencing 
Georefencing was carried out using Quantum GIS (GGIS, www.qgis.org ) plug-in by Andrade-Sanchez et al. (2014) during post processing. Latitude and longitude coordinates were converted to UTM coordinate system.  Offset from the sensors to the GPS position on the tractor heading were computed and corrected.  Next, the tractor data, which uses UTM Zone 12 (MAC coordinates), was transformed to EPSG:4326 (WGS84) USDA coordinates by performing  a linear shifting as follows:   
Latitude: Uy = My – 0.000015258894
Longitude: Ux = Mx + 0.000020308287 
where Uy and Ux are latitude and longitude in USDA coordinate system, and My and Mx are latitude and longitude in MAC coordinate system.
Finally, georeferenced tractor data was overlaid on the gantry field polygon and mean value for each plot/genotype was calculated using the data points that fall inside the plot polygon within ArcGIS Version 10.2 (ESRI. Redlands, CA).
Reference
Andrade-Sanchez, Pedro, et al. "Development and evaluation of a field-based high-throughput phenotyping platform." Functional Plant Biology 41.1 (2014): 68-79."
author: Andrade, Pedro
title: Maricopa Field Station Data and Metadata

name: Canopy cover estimation from ground-based conventional photographs
description:
This protocol describes a method for estimating canopy cover from photos obtained using conventional digital camera mounted on a custom-designed A-frame support. The images are processed with ImageJ to obtain an estimate of canopy cover.  The protocol steps and ImageJ settings and macro are described in the protocols.io open repository within the TERRA-REF group documents.  See the following link:  
https://www.protocols.io/private/62a12dab1aa66fbec0e2c02cfcec52cd​

title: Maricopa Agricultural Center Field Measurements and Activities

name: Scanner 3d ply data to height
description: height Estimation from 3D Scanner using formula: [hand height] = [(35th percentile from E + 35th percentile from W) / 2] cm * 0.97841 + 25.678cm.

title: Maricopa Field Station Data and Metadata

name: Mechanical harvest yield estimates Maricopa sorghum
description: Two rows were cut with a mounted universal forage harvester (Kemper Champion C 1200) and weighed in a custom-made weigh-wagon (Carter mgf).  Plant moisture content at harvest estimated from a subsample of the Kemper cuttings (green-chopped plant matter) collected in a cloth bag and dried in an oven at 60 C. Fresh weight and dry weight of the harvested plot expressed in kg/ha assuming plot dimensions of 1.524 m in width and 3.5 m in length.  Dry weight adjusted to 0% moisture basis. Moisture content calculated as (subsamplefresh-subsampledry)*100/subsamplefresh.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Grain near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) analysis
description:
Protein, fat, fiber, starch, and moisture content were measured using
NIRS at Texas A&M University’s sorghum breeding and
genetics lab. Approximately twenty grams of cleaned whole grain were
scanned with a FOSS XDS spectrometer (FOSS North
America, Eden Prairie, MN, USA). The NIR reflectance
spectra were recorded using the ISIscan software (Version
3.10.05933) and converted to estimates using in-house calibration curves and developed models.

name: RGB texture analysis
description:
This tool extracts color and texture features from an RGB image.
The color image is converted into a dark green color indexed (DGCI) image and the distribution of indexed value computed as intensity histogram.
Texture analysis is done by finding edges within the DGCI image and then counting the edge pixels.
author: NA
title: NA

name: In-season leaf area and biomass estimates by destructive sampling
description: Plant biomass was sampled from 1 meter of row on 8 June 2016 and 29 June 2016.  Stems were cut by hand near the soil surface and placed in a plastic bag for processing.  The number of plants in the sample and canopy height were recorded in the field.  The samples were then taken into the lab for processing.  The number of main stems and tillers in the entire sample were counted.  The entire sample was used on the 8 June 2016 sampling date and a subsample of 5 plants on the 29 June 2016 sampling date for further processing.  This 5-plant subsample (June 29) was weighed as well as the entire sample.  The leaves were then separated from the stems for leaf area measurements.  The fresh weight of the leaves and stems were measured for the 29 June 2016 sampling date.  Leaf area was measured using a LiCor  area meter and leaf area index (LAI) calculated by dividing leaf area by land area of the sample measured.  The land area representative of the leaf area measured was 0.762 m2 for the 8 June 2016 sampling date and 0.762 m2 times the subsample fraction for the 29 June 2016 sampling date.  The subsample fraction is defined as the weight of the subsample divided by the weight of the total sample.  The leaves and stems were then placed in an oven and dried at 65 C, and dry weight was measured after the plant material was dry.  The biomass of the stems and leaves on a dry weight basis were calculated from the measured dry weight divided by the land area representative of the processed sample for each sampling date as discussed above for leaf area.  Specific leaf area (for both sample dates) and dry matter fraction (for the June 29 sample date) were also calculated.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Leaf surface temperature and stomatal conductance estimates using hand-held instruments
description: Repeat measurements were taken using hand-held instruments to estimate leaf surface temperatures and leaf stomatal conductance within 6-8 select plots (3-4 accessions x 2 replicates) on 7 dates in mid to late June 2017 (sorghum season 4) as part of a focused field phenotyping campaign related to stomatal regulation.  Leaf surface temperatures were estimated using a FLIR TG167 Spot Thermal Camera (http://www.flir.com/instruments/tg167/) and an Apogee Infrared Radiometer Model MI-230 (https://www.apogeeinstruments.com/ultra-narrow-field-of-view-infrared-radiometer-with-handheld-meter-mi-230/).  Measurements were taken on sunlit leaves, targeting fully expanded when possible, at a distance of approximately 20 to 40 cm above the leaf surface.  Within each plot and at each measurement time, 6 total measurements were taken using the FLIR and Apogee instruments, with 3 measurements taken in each of the West and East subplot rows.  Leaf stomatal conductance was measured using a Decagon SC-1 Porometer (https://www.decagon.com/en/canopy/canopy-measurements/sc-1-leaf-porometer-stomatal-conductance-measurements/).  Within each plot and at each measurement time, 5 total measurements were taken using the porometer, on sunlit leaves targeting fully expanded leaves when possible.  On each of the 7 dates when measurements were taken, early morning baseline equilibrium readings starting at 5:45 to 6:00 for one cycle through all 8 plots.  Mid-day readings started at roughly 11:00 and continued through 3 repeat cycles of the 6-8 plots until roughly 15:00 to 16:00.  The porometer was calibrated at least once in the early morning and again before the mid-day readings.  The FLIR TG167 spot camera was tested against a thermal blackbody unit on 2017-06-21 (recorded 5 readings at 34.5 to 34.6 C while the thermal blackbody recorded 33.9 C).  During the later measurement dates, 2 plots were dropped from the repeat measurement cycles because they had grown out of reach for hand measurements.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Maricopa Agricultural Center Field Measurements and Activities

name: KSU Seedling Vigor
description:
1. Go through the field and identify five plots to use as standards that represent scores ranging from 1 to 5
Visit each plot
2. Go through the field to do seedling vigor phenotyping by compare the seedling with the standard plot
Score Plants
3. Assign a score between 1 and 5 to each plot using the scale developed from standard plots

Desiccation defined as premature cell death in younger leaves associated with injury or stress as opposed to senescence.

name: MultispeQ v1.0 field measurements of fluorescence-based and absorbance-based parameters
description:
Measurements of multiple photynthesis-related parameters were taken on sunlit leaves in the upper canopy using the handheld MultispeQ v1.0 instrument and the Leaf Photosynthesis protocol macro code developed by PhotosynQ Admin.  (https://photosynq.org/protocols/leaf-photosynthesis-multispeq-v1-0) 
Measurements made during August 2017 in the BAP experiment required a ladder to access leaves in the upper canopy.  Repeat measurements were taken on select plots between approximately 10:30 and 14:30, typically cycling through 8 plots (4 accessions x 2 reps) several times to establish a time series of the parameters centered around solar noon.  At each sampling time for each plot, 6 subsample measurements were taken within the plot.  During August 2017 irrigation treatments were implemented at two levels (water-deficit zones with no irrigation and well-watered zones irrigated for optimal plant water status).  Plots were selected for measurements within each of the two irrigation treatments.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Maricopa Agricultural Center Field Measurements and Activities

name: 98th_quantile_canopy_height
description: With ply file right clipped into plot level, compute histogram along Z-axis within the plot. Then integrate multiple height histogram in one plot(because we may have multiple scans per day) into one histogram. At last we output the 98th quantiles of histogram.
author: NA
title: NA

name: Scanner 3d ply data to leaf angle distribution
description: Leaf angle distribution is a key parameter to characterize canopy structure and plays a crucial role in controlling energy. The laser scanner in TERRA-REF gantry system is creating high throughput high resolution 3d plant models. We use 3d plant data to compute leaf normal orientation and then leads to leaf angle distribution. At last we generate two-parameter beta distribution and chi-parameter as our ‘single value traits’.
author: Zongyang, Li
title: Maricopa Field Station Data and Metadata

name: Scanner 3d ply data to 98th quantile height
description: With ply file right clipped into plot level, compute histogram along Z-axis within the plot. Then integrate multiple height histogram in one plot(because we may have multiple scans per day) into one histogram. At last we output the 98th quantiles of histogram.

name: Visual percent lodging estimate
description: Visually score percentage of plants in a plot that are lodged. 0 means no plant is lodged and 100 means all plants are completely lodged. The score is a subjective combination of the fraction of the plants lodged and the severity of lodging.

name: KSU emergence rate
description: Start to record three days after first observed seedling emergence and visit each plot every other day. 81 - 100 % seeds germinated - 5, 61 - 80 % seeds germinated - 4, 41 - 60 % seeds germinated - 3, 21 - 40 % seeds germinated - 2, 1 - 20% seeds germinated - 1, 0 % No germination - 0

name: Visual assessment of leaf dessication
description: Leaves were visually scored for the presence (1) or absence (0) of leaf dessication in the plot as judged by a trained indiviudal. Desication was considered tan to dark nectrotic tissue on a fullly emerged leaf.

name: plant emergence counts
description: The number of plants per plot or subplot were counted during emergence by visual assessment on multiple dates early in the season. The number of plants with >= 1 centimeter of green tissue above ground surface were counted.

name: Plant lodging incidence - Presence estimation

For each single reading, the probe is placed at ground level and at an angle such that the full length of the probe extends from the base of the main stems (planting line) of one row of a two-row plot to the base of the main stems (planting line) of the second row of the two-row plot.

title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Flag leaf position count
description: Position of the flag leaf based on number of elongated internodes and leaves on the main stem to the flag leaf, with 1 = first leaf to develop, increasing in consecutive integers up to the flag leaf.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Leaf to stem weight ratio estimate
description: Leaf to stem weight ratios estimates based on a small sample (5 to 10 plants) destructively sampled for in-season estimates of leaf area and fresh- and dry-weights on either a per-plant or ground area basis.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Stereo RGB data to emergence count
author: ZongyangLi
title: Maricopa Field Station Data and Metadata

name: Stem elongated internodes and basal tillers counts - visual repeat measures on marked plants
description: Multiple plants per plot were demarcated in the field early in the season using golf tees placed adjacent to the selected seedlings; numbers of leaves (internodes) were repeatedly counted on the same plant over time by permanently marking each new fully emerged leaf with the leaf number (1 = first leaf to develop) to capture temporal dynamics of growth. Numbers of tillers at each observation early in the season were also counted. Sorghum Crop Ontology Identifier CO_324:0000235 http://www.cropontology.org/terms/CO_324:0000235/Stem%20elongated%20internodes%20number/static-html?language=english; Basal tiller number was counted as the number of tillers with a fully emerged leaf. Sorghum Crop Ontology Identifier CO_324:0000344 http://www.cropontology.org/terms/CO_324:0000344/Plant%20basal%20tiller%20number%20-%20Counting/static-html?language=english
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: Leaf polyphenolics and chlorophyll measurements: Dualex Scientific+ leaf-clip handheld optical meter
description: The optical leaf-clip meter (Dualex Scientific+) uses 5 LED light sources, including 1 UV-A, 1 read and 2 near-infrared (NIR) and a silicon photodiode detector to estimate chlorophyll content in leaves as well as flavonol and anthocyanin contents in the leaf epidermis.  Measurements were taken on sunlit leaves in the upper canopy.  Within each sampled plot, multiple subsample measurements were taken, each on different leaves, targeting fully developed sunlit leaves when possible. The instrument reports 5 measurements:  1) the temperature of the optical emitting head, 2) chlorophyll index (=(NIR trans. - Red trans.)/Red trans), 3) flavonol index (=Log(NIR fluo. excited red/NIR fluo. excited UV-A), 4) anthocyanin index (=Log(NIR fluo. excited red/NIR fluo. excited green), and 5) NBI (proprietary) nitrogen status, Chl/Flav ratio.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Maricopa Agricultural Center Field Measurements and Activities

name: LAI estimates using LI-COR handheld LAI-2200C Plant Canopy Analyzer
description: The LAI (leaf area index) estimated nondestructively using LAI-2200C Plant Canopy Analyzer(LI-COR Inc., Lincoln, NE, USA) which allows users to operate under full sun condition without further requirements for sun angle. Measurements were conducted along a diagonal transect between the two plant rows of each sampled plot using the 45°view restrictor to hide the user from the sensor Field of View(FOV). Two above-canopy measurements were taken at the beginning and end of the plant rows; five below-canopy measurements were taken along the transect at even spacing by placing the sensor on the ground to assure maximum coverage of the plant canopy in the sensor FOV.
author: NA
title: NA

name: Visual assessment of maturity stage at harvest
description: Sorghum growth stage descriptions follow Vanderlip RL. 1993. How a sorghum plant develops. Manhattan, KS, USA: Kansas State University Cooperative Extension. Growth stages grouped by the following categories: vegetative growth prior to flag leaf emergence; flag leaf fully emerged; flowering (anthesis); early, mid, and late grain fill. Numerical categories: 1 = Vegetative; 2 = Flag leaf; 3 = Flowering; 4 = Early grain fill; 5 = Mid grain fill; 6 = Late grain fill.  Early grain fill defined as time from flowering to milk or soft dough stages. Mid grain fill includes soft dough stage. Late grain fill defined as just past soft dough to physiological maturity.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center

name: In-season per-plant leaf area and biomass estimates by destructive sampling
description: Five plants of median height selected from all plants within 1 meter section of the plot row. The five destructively sampled plants were processed for per-plant leaf area and biomass estimates. All leaves, fully emerged and emerging, were removed from the main stem of each of the five plants and run through leaf area meter to estimate total leaf area per plant (cm2).  Leaves of all five plants were pooled to measure combined leaf fresh weight. Main stems of all five plants were pooled to measure combined stem fresh weight.  Leaf and stem samples were placed in drying oven at 60 C for two days.  Dry weights of leaf and stem samples were measured as the combined weights of all five plants.
author: Newcomb, Maria
title: Maricopa Agricultural Center Field Measurements and Activities
